dt: {bc}a typically curved structural member spanning an opening and serving as a support (as for the wall or other weight above the opening)
{bc}something resembling an arch in form or function
{bc}either of two vaulted portions of the bony structure of the foot that impart {d_link|elasticity|elasticity} to it
{bc}something that has a curved shape like an arch

dt.t: There was a slight {wi}arch{/wi} in her eyebrows.

art.capt: arch 1: {it}1{/it} round: {it}imp{/it} impost, {it}sp{/it} springer, {it}v{/it} voussoir, {it}k{/it} keystone, {it}ext{/it} extrados, {it}int{/it} intrados; {it}2{/it} horseshoe; {it}3{/it} lancet; {it}4{/it} ogee; {it}5{/it} trefoil; {it}6{/it} basket-handle; {it}7{/it} Tudor

et: Middle English {it}arche{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Vulgar Latin {it}*arca{/it}, from Latin {it}arcus{/it} {ma}{mat|arrow|}{/ma}
shortdef: a typically curved structural member spanning an opening and serving as a support (as for the wall or other weight above the opening)
something resembling an arch in form or function; especially : either of two vaulted portions of the bony structure of the foot that impart elasticity to it
something that has a curved shape like an arch

dt: {bc}to cover or provide with an arch

shortdef: to cover or provide with an arch

dt: {bc}marked by a deliberate and often forced playfulness, irony, or impudence

dt.t: … decided to answer them by being teacherly in a sort of {wi}arch{/wi}, Olympian way.

shortdef: marked by a deliberate and often forced playfulness, irony, or impudence

dt: {bc}extreme {bc}most fully embodying the qualities of the kind

et: Middle English {it}arche-, arch-{/it}, from Old English & Anglo-French; Old English {it}arce-{/it}, from Late Latin {it}arch-{/it} & Latin {it}archi-{/it}; Anglo-French {it}arch-{/it}, from Late Latin {it}arch-{/it} & Latin {it}archi-{/it}, from Greek {it}arch-, archi-{/it}, from {it}archein{/it} to begin, rule; akin to Greek {it}archē{/it} beginning, rule, {it}archos{/it} ruler
shortdef: extreme : most fully embodying the qualities of the kind

et: Middle English {it}-arche{/it}, from Anglo-French & Late Latin & Latin; Anglo-French {it}-arche{/it}, from Late Latin {it}-archa{/it}, from Latin {it}-arches, -archus{/it}, from Greek {it}-archēs, -archos{/it}, from {it}archein{/it}

dt: {bc}having (such) a point or (so many) points of origin

et: probably from German, from Greek {it}archē{/it} beginning
shortdef: having (such) a point or (so many) points of origin

et: French or Latin; French, from Latin, from Greek {ma}{mat|arch-|}{/ma}
